revision.text:
The '''Moldovan schools in Transnistria''' became an issue of contention in 2004 in the context of the [[disputed status of Transnistria]], a breakaway region of [[Moldova]] since 1990/1992.
== History == Moldovan schools were first established in Transnistria after the 1924 formation of the [[Moldovan Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]], which was part of the Soviet Republic of [[Ukraine]]. In 1940 the former Moldovan Autonomous Republic was split, 8 districts were included in the [[Ukraine|Soviet Socialist Republic of Ukraine]] and 6 districts were joined with part of [[Basarabia]] in the [[Republic of Moldova|Soviet Socialist Republic of Moldavia]]. In the Ukrainian part of the former Moldavian autonomy Moldovan schools were transformed into Russian-language schools, but in the 6 districts that remained part of the [[Republic of Moldova|Soviet Socialist Republic of Moldova]] a Moldovan-language network of schools was kept.
==Post 1992 situation==
The Moldovan 1989 language law, that introduced the Latin script as the official script of the Republic of Moldova, was boycotted by the Transnistrian authorities, and all Moldovan schools in Transnistria were ordered to keep the Cyrillic script. After the [[War of Transnistria]] ended in mid-1992, the local schools became regulated by the government of Transnistria. The schools that chose to use the Latin script back in 1989 came under pressure of the authorities and most were forced to return to the Cyrillic script. Only six Romanian language schools in Transnistria were allowed to keep the Latin script.
Attempts to expand the number of schools which are using Latin script are met with heavy-handed repression. In 1996, the director of the only Moldovan school in [[Slobozia, Moldova|Slobozia]], who supported the wish of the parents to conduct education in Latin alphabet was fired and forced to leave the region. In 1999 a lecturer of Moldovan language of the Bender Pedagogical College has been dismissed for promoting the Latin script in the institution. The dismissal has been preceded by threats on the phone and an aggression in the building where she lived.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20050619192931/http://www.coe.int/t/e/human_rights/minorities/3._co-operation_activities/1._co-operation_activities/2._stability_pact_activities/PDF_SP_NDR%282002%29011%20Preliminary_Report_Moldova.pdf Non discrimination review under the stability pact for South Eastern Europe]</ref>
In September 1996, the [[Grigoriopol]] administration used Cossacks and police to stop the activity of Moldovan School.<ref>[http://transnistria.md/en/interview/0/126/5 Interview with Eleonora Cecavski, teacher from Grigoriopol] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927024802/http://transnistria.md/en/interview/0/126/5 |date=27 September 2007 }}</ref> On 2 October 1996 three teachers were arrested and taken to Tiraspol. On 7 October 1996, as a result of a demarche by the President of the Republic of Moldova and the OSCE Mission, the teachers were released.
Another attempt to teach Romanian clandestinely in Grigoriopol, in a ‘PMR state-funded school’, failed in 2002. Teaching staff and parents were blatantly vilified in the local press as ‘enemies of the State’.<ref>[http://www.unhcr.md/article/ld15.htm BIG SCANDAL IN A SMALL TOWN, article in "Dnestrovsky Kurier" 8 March 2002] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060912130836/http://www.unhcr.md/article/ld15.htm |date=12 September 2006 }}</ref> One by one they were invited to ‘reconsider’, threatened with loss of employment and the corresponding entitlement to housing. Children (and teachers) were forced to write explanations as to why they used the Latin script and local officials routinely visited classes to check whether tuition was being ‘properly’ conducted. The parent-teacher association was abolished and its head, [[Mihai Speian]], was arrested.<ref>[http://www.soviet-medals-orders.com/images/Publ/andrysek&grecu4.htm Unworthy partner: the schools issue as an example of human rights abuses in Transdniestria] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820031858/http://www.soviet-medals-orders.com/images/Publ/andrysek%26grecu4.htm |date=20 August 2016 }}</ref> The Moldovan school in Grigoriopol was forced to move in [[Doroţcaia|Doroțcaia]], a village controlled by Chișinău, and children commute 10–15 km daily to attend the school.
== The 2004 crisis == In the summer of 2004, the Transnistrian authorities closed four of the six schools in the region that taught [[Moldovan language]] using the [[Latin]] script, known as Romanian. Some of the 3,400 enrolled children were affected by this measure and the teachers and parents who opposed the closures were temporarily arrested for up to six hours. During the crisis, the Moldovan government decided to create a blockade that would isolate the disputed region from the rest of the world. The blockade was ineffective because of a lack of cooperation from [[Ukraine]], led at the time by [[Leonid Kuchma]]. Transnistria retaliated with a series of actions meant to destabilize the economic situation in Moldova, in particular, by cutting the power supply from the power plants that were built in Transnistria in [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] times. As a result, this crisis generated power outages in parts of Moldova.
A leading figure in the conflict was [[Elena Vasilievna Bomeshko]], the Minister of Education for Transnistria. According to her, and official Transnistrian policy, the language is referred to as "[[Romanian language|Romanian]]" when it is taught in Latin script and referred to as "Moldovan" when [[Cyrillic]] script is used. Transnistria rejects accusations of anti-Romanian bias and defends its preference of Cyrillic for Moldovan as a way to maintain the original language, pointing to the fact as far back as the Middle Ages, Moldovan [[Bible]]s were always written in Cyrillic.<ref>[http://www.tiras.ru/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1381 Interview with V. Tulgar, Union of Moldovans] {{dead link|date=February 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} (in Russian)</ref> While the Romanian language used the Cyrillic alphabet for centuries, it is no longer used in Romania. Cyrillic script is still used in some parts of Moldova, but only one newspaper (state-owned by Transnistrian authorities) prints a few hundred copies in Cyrillic.<ref>[http://www.rgnpress.ro/content/view/18846// RGN Press report: No Romanian language textbooks available in Grigoriopol.]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (in Romanian)</ref>
The closed Romanian schools were reopened, after registering as private institutions with the Transnistrian authorities. Pressure from the European Union (a travel ban was introduced to 10 Transnistrian education officials) may have sped up the process.,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.consilium.europa.eu/uedocs/cmsUpload/ChildrenHRDecember2005.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-30 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160623160752/http://www.consilium.europa.eu/uedocs/cmsUpload/ChildrenHRDecember2005.pdf |archivedate=23 June 2016 |df=dmy }} pp. 17-18: "''The Council adopted a Decision implementing common position 2004/179/CFSP on restrictive measures against the leadership of the Transnistrian region of Moldova (15061/05). [...] The Decision reduces the list of persons (from ten to two) affected by visa restrictions in order to take account of the improvements in the situation of Latin-script schools in some areas of the Transnistrian region. In August 2004, the Council expanded the scope of the restrictive measures to persons held responsible for the intimidation campaign and the closure of Latin-script Moldovan schools and established a new list of persons subject to the visa-ban.''"</ref> but they still have the status of "private schools" and consequently do not receive funding from the Transnistrian government.
Many teachers and parents of students studying at Moldovan schools with Cyrillic script had contacted the Moldovan Helsinki Committee for Human Rights asking support to turn education in Romanian (Latin script), as the studies based on the Cyrillic script and Soviet curricula don't have any perspective and the children are unable to pursue higher studies anywhere.<ref>[http://www.azi.md/news?ID=31564 Helsinki-Moldova Committee Says About 50 Schools in Transnistria Want to Study in Romanian] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927175634/http://www.azi.md/news?ID=31564 |date=27 September 2007 }}</ref> The OSCE [[High Commissioner on National Minorities]] has condemned the actions of Transnistrian authorities as a "linguistic cleansing".<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20160218033937/http://www.osce.org/hcnm/56534 OSCE: Linguistic cleansing underway in Transdniestria]</ref>
==Current situation== [[File:Liceul Alexandru cel Bun Tighina 13.jpg|thumb|Students at Alexandru cel Bun High School in Bender celebrating the end of the academic year in May 2013]] An OSCE report from June 2005 states: “If they [Moldovan parents in Transnistria] enroll their children in one of this schools that offer a Moldovan curriculum using a Latin script, they risk being threatened by the regional security service, and seeing their jobs put in jeopardy. Sending their children in one of the 33 Transdniestrian schools they teach in their native language in Cyrillic is, however, hardly an appealing alternative, as the schools follow an out-dated curriculum and use textbooks from the Soviet period”.<ref>[http://www.osce.org/documents/html/pdftohtml/15621_425_en.pdf.html OSCE report: Moldovan schools in Transdniestria] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606163208/http://www.osce.org/documents/html/pdftohtml/15621_425_en.pdf.html |date=6 June 2011 }}</ref> This is the reason why many Moldovans from [[Transnistria]] send their children in harassment-free Russian language schools.
Transnistrian authorities don't recognize the diplomas issued by Moldovan schools using Latin script, making impossible for graduates of those schools to study on Transnistrian higher educational institutions.<ref>[http://tiraspoltimes.com/news/education_ministry_see_minority_schools_as_pawn_in_political_game.html Transnistrian point of view about Moldovan schools] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930024100/http://tiraspoltimes.com/news/education_ministry_see_minority_schools_as_pawn_in_political_game.html |date=30 September 2007 }}</ref>
===Involvement of European Court of Human Rights=== In November 2006 the European Court of Human Rights accepted to examine the claims submitted by three Moldovan schools in Transnistria (from Tighina, Rîbnița and Grigoriopol) regarding the violation of their right to education and right to work in conditions of non-discrimination. The three schools concerned regard Russia and Moldova as responsible for violation of their rights.<ref>[http://conflict.md/stiri.php?ID=1918 ECHR TO CONSIDER CLAIMS LODGED BY MOLDOVAN SCHOOLS IN TRANSNISTRIA] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927005441/http://conflict.md/stiri.php?ID=1918 |date=27 September 2007 }}</ref> In June 2009, the Court conducted hearings on three similar cases: Caldare and 42 Others v. Moldova and Russia (no. 8252/05), Catan and 27 Others v. Moldova and Russia (no. 43370/04), Cervaschi and 98 Others v. Moldova and Russia (no. 18454/06).<ref>[http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=851010&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 ECHR press release] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120612115041/http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=851010&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 |date=12 June 2012 }}</ref> In 2010, the Court has decided the case to be partly admissible<ref>[http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=871403&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 Admissibility decision on applications nos. 43370/04, 8252/05 and 18454/06] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120612115054/http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=871403&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 |date=12 June 2012 }}</ref> In 2012, the Court decided that the right to education of the applicants was violated by Russia, but not violated by Moldova.<ref>[http://hudoc.echr.coe.int/sites/fra/pages/search.aspx?i=001-114082 ECtHR Grand Chamber judgment in case ''Catan and Others v. Moldova and Russia'' (appolications nos. 43370/04 18454/06 8252/05)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906053543/http://hudoc.echr.coe.int/sites/fra/pages/search.aspx?i=001-114082 |date=6 September 2015 }} 19.10.2012</ref>
=== Pressure on Transnistrian authorities === In November 2006, [[Louis O'Neill]], head of OSCE mission to Moldova, has urged local authorities in the Transnistrian city of Rîbnița to return a confiscated building to the Moldovan Latin-script school located in the city. The building was built by the Government from Chișinău and was almost finished in 2004, when Transnistrian police took it by force, during the school crisis.<ref>[http://www.osce.org/item/22208.html?print=1 Ribnitsa authorities must return confiscated school building, says OSCE Mission Head] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303195911/http://www.osce.org/item/22208.html?print=1 |date=3 March 2016 }}</ref>
<!-- == Villages without Romanian language schools == * 3 villages with 100% Moldovan population with only Russian-language schools: Cuzmin ([[Camenca district]]), Broșteni, Lenino ([[Rîbniţa district|Rîbnița district]]). * 5 villages with Moldovan majority with only Russian-language schools: Vadul Turcului, Sovetskoe, Mocra ([[Rîbniţa district|Rîbnița district]]), Comisarovca Nouă ([[Dubăsari district]]), Gîrtop ([[Grigoriopol district]]). * 4 villages with around 50% Moldovans with only Russian-language schools: Zozuliani ([[Rîbniţa district|Rîbnița district]]), Crasnoie, Glinoia ([[Slobozia district]]), Protiagailovca (near [[Tighina]]). * 21 villages with 100% Moldovan population, without any schools: Frunzovca, Podoimița ([[Camenca district]]), Vasilievca, Saraței, Vladimirovca, Zaporojeț, Besarabca, Jurca ([[Rîbniţa district|Rîbnița district]]), Goianul Nou, Vasilievca, Afanasievca, Alexandrovca Nouă, Bosca ([[Dubăsari district]]), Pobeda, Kotovca, Bruslachi, Mocriachi, Marian, Crasnoe, India, Tocmazeia ([[Grigoriopol district]]). * 2 villages with Moldovan majority without any schools: Butuciani ([[Rîbniţa district|Rîbnița district]]), Priozornoie ([[Slobozia district]]). * 12 villages with important Moldovan minority and only Russian-language schools: Gidirim, Voroncău, Popenchi ([[Rîbniţa district|Rîbnița district]]), Doibani 2, Jerjinscoe ([[Dubăsari district]]), Hlinaia, Șipca ([[Grigoriopol district]]), Vladimirovca, Frunze, Pervomaisc, Cremenciug, Dnestrovsc ([[Slobozia district]]).<ref>[http://tdsu.idknet.com/region/english/atlas/dir22/chisl_k.jpg Ethnografic map of Transnistria, according to transnistrian authorities] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060716185737/http://tdsu.idknet.com/region/english/atlas/dir22/chisl_k.jpg |date=16 July 2006 }}</ref><ref>[http://tdsu.idknet.com/region/english/atlas/dir10/scools.jpg Map of Transnistrian schools, according to transnistrian authorities] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060714172207/http://tdsu.idknet.com/region/english/atlas/dir10/scools.jpg |date=14 July 2006 }}</ref> -->

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Openowledge | native_name = 오픈놀리지 | former_name = Khan Academy Korea | image = File:Openowledge_Logo,_2014.jpg | image_border = | size = 200px | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = The official logo for Openowledge | map = | msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | malt = <!-- map alt text --> | mcaption = | map2 = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = <!-- {{Start date and age|2013|01|DD}} --> | founder = <!-- or | founders = -->Yu, Jin-Woo | extinction = <!-- {{End date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | merged = | type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] | status = active | purpose = Online Knowledge Sharing | professional_title = <!-- for professional associations -->오픈놀리지:대한민국을 밝히는 지식나눔 플랫폼 | headquarters = | location = 부산시 북구 화명동 2306 717-803 | coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using {{Coord}} --> | region_served = | services = | membership = | language = [[Korean (language)|Korean]], [[English (language)|English]] | general = <!-- Secretary General --> | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> | parent_organization = <!-- if one --> | subsidiaries = | affiliations = | budget = | num_staff = 8 | num_volunteers= 40 | slogan = | website = http://openowledge.com/opencourse/|openowledge.com | remarks = | footnotes = }} '''Openowledge''' (Korean:오픈놀리지) is an educational and [[nonprofit organization]] managed by students of [[CheongShim International Academy]]. The project was launched on January 2013 by the founder Jin-Woo Yu. The stated mission is to "allow students in [[South Korea]] to easily learn and study the lectures on their website.
The courses on the site includes videos translated from [[Khan Academy]] as well as those originally created by students. The subjects include: [[Calculus]], [[Western Philosophy]], Problems in [[Economics]], and [[neuroscience]]. The total number of views is estimated to be about 26,300.<ref name="November News">{{cite news |last=Choi (최) |first=HwaJin (화진) |url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/society/schooling/610715.html |script-title=ko:외국 동영상 번역하고 친구 강의도 제작해요 |publisher=The Hankyoreh |date=November 11, 2013 |accessdate=November 21, 2013 |language=Korean |trans-title=We translate foreign videos and create lectures given by friends}}</ref>
==History== One of the founders, Jin-Woo Yu, was inspired by a [[Article (publishing)|news article]] which introduced [[Khan Academy]]. He stated that the concept of Openowledge was created from a desire to create a translated and better-organized site.<ref name="November News" /> Another member stated that the concept of [[Korean (language)|Korean]] subtitles arose from her own experience with Khan Academy.<ref name="August News">{{cite news |url=http://news.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2013/08/21/2013082102411.html |script-title=ko:세상 모든 지식 나눌 수 있는 다리 만들래요 |publisher=chosun.com |date=August 22, 2013 |accessdate=November 21, 2013 |language=Korean |trans-title=We'll create a bridge to share all the knowledge in the world}}</ref> In 2012, Jin-Woo Yu and Myung-Gun Seo created the organization Khan Academy Korea. Khan Academy Korea had a project to translate Khan Academy videos. The project was extended into the current Openowledge project.<ref name="June News">{{cite news |url=http://news.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2013/06/10/2013061002202.html |script-title=ko:[더 나은 미래] 온라인 지식 공유의 場… 가난·언어·지역의 울타리 허물다 |publisher=chosun.com |date=June 11, 2013 |accessdate=November 21, 2013 |language=Korean |trans-title=[A Better Future] A place of online knowledge... Ridding of barriers of poverty and language}}</ref>
The first rough form of the organization began on the beginning of 2013 with founder Yu Jin-Woo and two others.<ref name="November News" /> At least one advertisement appeared on November 22, 2013.<ref name="Blog">{{cite web |last=Yu (유) |first=JinWoo (진우) |last2=Jung (정) |first2=YoungWook (용욱) |url=http://noonblog.tistory.com/22 |title=오픈놀리지(Openowledge)를 소개합니다 |publisher=쥐이이누's Blog |accessdate=November 21, 2013 |language=Korean |trans-title=Introducing Openowledge}}</ref> On January 2013,'Openowledge' was first created<ref name="June News" /> as a [[high school club]].<ref name="November News" /> The founders only consisted of second-year [[high school]] students in [[CheongShim International Academy]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Bak (박) |first=JooSong (주성) |url=http://www.newsis.com/gallery/view.htm?cID=2&pID=1&page=1&s_skin=&s_date=&e_date=&s_k=&pict_id=NISI20130716_0008437416 |script-title=ko:학생들의 지식나눔 프로젝트 '오픈놀리지' 정식 오픈 |publisher=NEWSIS.COM |date=July 16, 2013 |accessdate=November 21, 2013 |language=Korean |trans-title=Students' knowledge-sharing project 'Openowledge' officially open}}</ref> The current site began operating on May 2013<ref name="November News" /><ref name="July List">{{cite news |last=Lee (이) |first=SoonHyuk (순혁) |url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/economy/it/597878.html |script-title=ko:클릭! 나는 공짜로 공부한다 |publisher=The Hankyoreh |date=July 31, 2013 |accessdate=November 21, 2013 |language=Korean |trans-title=Click! I'm studying for free}}</ref> as a beta version for about a month. Openowledge started operating as an actual service on July 16, 2013.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bak (박) |first=JooSong (주성) |url=http://www.newsis.com/gallery/view.htm?cID=2&pID=1&page=1&s_skin=&s_date=&e_date=&s_k=&pict_id=NISI20130716_0008437415 |script-title=ko:학생들의 지식나눔 프로젝트 '오픈놀리지' 정식 오픈 |publisher=NEWSIS.COM |date=July 16, 2013 |accessdate=November 21, 2013 |language=Korean |trans-title=Students' knowledge-sharing project 'Openowledge' officially open |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203011625/http://www.newsis.com/gallery/view.htm?cID=2&pID=1&page=1&s_skin=&s_date=&e_date=&s_k=&pict_id=NISI20130716_0008437415 |archivedate=December 3, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
Openowledge has since registered as an official organization.<ref name="November News" /> It is now classified as an educational, [[nonprofit organization]].<ref name="June News" /> It is also classified as an official [[volunteering]] organization.<ref name="August News" />
==Organization== Openowledge is maintained by eight CheongShim International Academy students.<ref name="November News" /> Openowledge is divided into three parts: The 'share-knowledge' project, the '[[foreign language]] content [[translation]] project' and the 'CheongShim Opencourseware (OCW).'<ref name="Introduction">{{cite web |url=http://openowledge.com/opencourse/%EC%98%A4%ED%94%88%EB%86%80%EB%A6%AC%EC%A7%80-%EC%86%8C%EA%B0%9C/ |script-title=ko:오픈놀리지 소개 |publisher=Openowledge |accessdate=November 21, 2013 |language=Korean |trans-title=Openowledge Introduction}}</ref>
The share-knowledge project consists of videos created by CheongShim International Academy high-school students.<ref name="Introduction" /> The subjects include: [[Calculus]], [[Western Philosophy]], Problems in [[Economics]], and [[neuroscience]].<ref name="July List" /> The lecturers include a participant in the [[International Philosophy Olympiad]] and other students considered 'great lecturers.'<ref name="August News" /> The contents are shown for free on the website.<ref name="Introduction" /> As of August 2013, 32 original videos are available on the website.<ref name="August News" />
The foreign language content translation project consists of videos translated from Khan Academy and MIT+K12.<ref name="Introduction" /> Translators ranges from [[elementary school]] students to [[college]] students and employed adults. As of November 2013, there are about 40 translators in total.<ref name="November News" /> Members estimate that the translation time for one video is about two hours. There are special translation teams such as 'ACG Translation Team' which translates the videos.<ref name="August News" /> Currently, a translation team consists of two or three members.<ref name="July List" /> The videos are shown free on the website.<ref name="Introduction" /> As of August 2013, there were about 35 translated lectures on the website.<ref name="August News" />
The CheongShim Opencourseware consists of original lectures produced by CheongShim International Academy teachers. The videos are uploaded for free on the website and on [[YouTube]].<ref name="Introduction" />
==Future Plans== The founder Yu, Jin-Woo have stated that he hopes to have a total of 500 lecturers and 800 lectures by 2015 and have Openowledge named as the 'most diverse knowledge-sharing platform in the [[Republic of Korea]].'<ref name="August News" />
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Educational websites]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Original research|date=January 2008}} {{unreferenced|date=January 2008}} }}
The '''Organised Independents''' (often abbreviated to '''OIs''') are a grouping within the [[National Union of Students (United Kingdom)|National Union of Students of the United Kingdom]].
The group is made up of candidates for [[Governance of the National Union of Students (United Kingdom)#National Executive Committee|National Executive Committee]] posts, all standing on an "independent" label, and their supporters.<ref name="Brooks">{{cite book|author1=Rachel Brooks|title=Student Politics and Protest: International perspectives|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UM5CDQAAQBAJ|year=2016|publisher=Routledge|page=148|isbn=978-0-8203-3496-7|access-date=October 14, 2016|archive-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UM5CDQAAQBAJ|archive-date=April 30, 2017}}</ref> As such, the OIs have been defined as an [[interest group]] as opposed to a [[political faction|faction]]; this originates from the idea that they are [[apoliticism|apolitical]] or [[moderate]], either simply as a group of [[sabbatical officer|sabbatical officers]] seeking to support one another, or as proponents of a [[Student unionism in the United Kingdom|membership]]-focused national ideology. Commentator Rachel Brooks writes that the OIs also have a "shared concern to minimise the influence of 'the left'," which she defines as centring around the factions [[Alliance for Workers Liberty|AWL]], [[Student Broad Left|Liberation Left]], and [[National Campaign Against Fees and Cuts|NCAFC]].<ref name="Brooks"></ref>
In 2017, after [[Malia Bouattia#Allegations of antisemitism|widespread discontentment]] with NUS under the leadership of [[Malia Bouattia]], a [[slate (elections)|slate]] of OI-backed candidates won five of the six [[Governance of the National Union of Students (United Kingdom)#Full Time Officers|full-time officer positions]] elected at NUS National Conference. This included the role of President in which [[Shakira Martin (NUS)|Shakira Martin]], the union's vice-president for further education, defeated Bouattia, receiving 56% of the vote.<ref name="Topping">{{cite news|last1=Topping|first1=Alexandra|last2=Marsh|first2=Sarah|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2017/apr/26/malia-bouattia-shakira-martin-nus-national-union-of-students-president-election|title=Divisive NUS president Malia Bouattia defeated in election|work=The Guardian|date=26 April 2017|accessdate=26 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="Peake">{{cite news|last1=Peake|first1=Emili|url=http://www.thenationalstudent.com/Student/2017-04-28/abortion_rights_mental_health_and_climate_change_amongst_20_motions_passed_at_nus_conference.html|title=Abortion rights, mental health and climate change amongst 20 motions passed at NUS Conference|work=The National Student|date=28 April 2017|accessdate=28 April 2017}}</ref>
{{Infobox non-profit | name = Organised Independents | image = [[File:Organised Independents logo, 2017.png|Organised Independents logo, 2017|200px|Image: 200 pixels]] | type = Student Union | tax_id = | founded_date = {{Start date and age|1999}} | founder = | location = [[London, UK]] | coordinates = | origins = | key_people = | area_served = The United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland | focus = | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = | former name = Webberites, Owainites, Independent Faction | homepage = {{URL|www.theyworkforus.co.uk}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
==Ideology== While individual OIs have a broad range of political views and positions, from [[soft left]] to [[one-nation conservatism]], the group as a whole holds a [[Student unionism in the United Kingdom|membership]]-focused ideology. The group advocates the NUS being more directly representative of its member SUs, often invoking the motto that 'they work for us'.
As a result, OI policy positions are often more socially [[Left-wing politics|left-wing]] than factions such as the [[Labour Students]] or [[UJS|Union of Jewish Students]], but tend to avoid non-education policy areas prioritised by [[NCAFC]] or [[Student Broad Left|Liberation Left]] such as [[Economic policy|economic]] or [[foreign policy]]. An exception to this was on [[Brexit]], which prominent OIs took a strong stance against, and the group led [[For our Future's Sake|NUS' campaign]] for a [[People's Vote|people's vote]].<ref name="ShoutoutUK">{{cite news|last1=Pontone|first1=Maya|title=Vice President of NUS mobilises ‘people’s vote’ on final Brexit deal|url=https://www.shoutoutuk.org/2018/03/30/vice-president-of-nus-mobilises-peoples-vote-on-final-brexit-deal/}}</ref>
==History==
===Background=== {{Unreferenced section|date=April 2017}} As a result of the group's broad definition, a lot of controversy has raged over whether such a faction exists. Many NUS commentators are in agreement that such an organised grouping is clearly in existence. Various names were in use, including the "Webberites" (after Simon Webber, an early leading figure), the "Owainites" (after [[Owain James]], NUS President 2000-2002), the "Independent Faction" before the term "Organised Independents" took hold. The phrase "independent student officers" was also prominent on many manifestos. Increasingly members of the grouping no longer dispute their existence and the label. However, there is still much dispute over whether or not individual independents are aligned to the OIs or not.
===1990-2002=== {{Refimprove|section|date=May 2017}} The OIs emerged as a group of independent candidates and NEC members who gave support to the [[Labour Students]]-dominated NUS leadership of the 1990s. Several admitted to being "members of the Labour Party but not Labour Students," a distinction that some found difficult to understand. Further confusion reigned as some OIs appeared to be members of Labour Students at the ordinary level. The group became increasingly prominent in 2000 when Labour Students declined to put up a candidate to defend the Presidency of the NUS, a position which they had previously held for eighteen years, but instead backed Owain James as an independent, who won the post and held it for the two years allowed under the constitution. Former NUS [[National Union of Students LGBT+ Campaign|LGB officer]] Carli Harper-Pennan wrote that at this time, the OIs were "aligned with Labour Students", "organised with them", and had "the same agenda".<ref name="Harper-Pennan">{{cite news|last1=Rudebeck|first1=Clare|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/higher/its-tough-at-the-top-and-dirty-9204208.html|title=It's tough at the top - and dirty|work=The Independent|date=3 April 2002|accessdate=28 April 2017}}</ref>
===2002-2010=== {{Refimprove|section|date=May 2017}} The 2002 NUS elections saw the OIs and Labour Students fall out and run opposing candidates. In general the OIs defeated the Labour Students in all elections bar the Presidency, which was won by [[Mandy Telford]]. Subsequently, the OIs and Labour Students fluctuated between co-operation at times, but fierce opposition at others. It was in this 2004-6 period that the later-Mayor of [[London Borough of Islington|Islington]] [[Kat Fletcher]] of CFE/[[Alliance for Workers Liberty|AWL]] was elected President; Fletcher was the first since 1981 to be elected from a political slate clearly to the left of either Labour Students or the OIs. In recent years there has therefore been renewed confusion over the exact membership of the OIs, stemming from a series of notable factional shifts within the NUS by several individuals and the emergence of more than one group of independents who organise together.
In 2007, though, the position was clear, and the independents who described themselves within NUS formally as OIs were [[Gemma Tumelty]] (National President), Stephen Brown (National Secretary), Ama Uzowuru (Vice-President Welfare), Adam McNicholas (Block of 12). Tumelty and Brown both left their respective posts in June 2008.
The Organised Independents continued to be popular within the national movement. 2008 saw the appearance of the 'Dirty Games' deal, in which the OIs were reported to have been "handed the vice-president higher education position for [[Aaron Porter]]", in exchange for backing the later [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]] [[Wes Streeting]] for President.<ref name="Walker">{{cite news|last1=Walker|first1=Tom|url=http://www.national-student.co.uk/national_news/dirty_games_nus_presidential_election_stitch_up.htm|title=“Dirty Games” - NUS presidential election stitch-up|work=The National Student|date=11 March 2008|accessdate=28 April 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20080314150017/http://www.national-student.co.uk/national_news/dirty_games_nus_presidential_election_stitch_up.htm|archivedate=14 March 2008|df=}}</ref> In the 2008 elections, Porter was elected, while Ama Uzowuru was re-elected as Vice-President (Welfare), and Ben Whittaker and Elizabeth Sommerville were elected onto the Block of 12. The Organised Independents were also in power in NUS Scotland, with Gurjit Singh holding Presidency in 2008. He was defeated in the following presidential election by Labour party member Liam Burns.
In 2009, Whittaker was elected as Vice President Welfare and Liz Williams (Liverpool Guild of Students) and Alice Bouquet (University of West England SU) were elected onto Block of 15 at National Conference. Katie Dalton was elected President of NUS Wales.
In 2010, Porter was elected as the [[List of Presidents of the National Union of Students (United Kingdom)|54th President]] of the [[National Union of Students (United Kingdom)|National Union of Students]]. Whittaker was re-elected Vice President (Welfare). Peter Mercer and Ryan Wain were elected onto Block of 15. Katie Dalton was also re-elected President of NUS Wales.
===2010-2017=== {{Refimprove|section|date=May 2017}} In 2011, Peter Mercer was elected Vice-President Welfare following Ben Whittaker's two terms. Matthew East, two-term Anglia Ruskin Students' Union President, was elected onto the Block of 15. George-Konstantinos Charonis was elected as the NUS Postgraduate Taught Representative at the Postgraduate Conference.
The OIs were temporarily disbanded after this, until the [[National Union of Students (United Kingdom)#2017 National Conference|2017 National Conference]]. In 2013, however, Raechel Mattey and Colum McGuire were elected as VP Union Development and VP Welfare, respectively; they continued to campaign informally around [[moderate]] candidates and issues. Both were re-elected to serve a second term in 2014. Mattey grew unpopular, however; at the 2013 [[Governance of the National Union of Students (United Kingdom)#Zones|Union Development zone]] conference, she had refused to allow a [[National Campaign Against Fees and Cuts|NCAFC]]<ref>[https://www.opendemocracy.net/author/james-mcash] OpenDemocracy. Retrieved 01 May 2017.</ref> member of her [[Governance of the National Union of Students (United Kingdom)#Zones|zone committee]] to enter the accountability session, and gained a reputation for being unaccountable and afraid of challenge.
In 2015, following Mattey, Richard Brooks was elected Vice President (Union Development).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nusconnect.org.uk/articles/richard-brooks-elected-as-nus-vice-president-union-development|title=Richard Brooks elected as NUS Vice President (Union Development)|last= |first= |date=April 22, 2015 |website=NUS Connect|publisher=NUS Connect|access-date=April 30, 2017 |quote=}}</ref> Vonnie Sandlan and Fergal McFerran were also elected Presidents of [[National Union of Students Scotland|NUS Scotland]] and [[National Union of Students-Union of Students in Ireland|NUS-USI]], respectively.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nus-usi.org/2015/01/16/person-1/|title=Fergal McFerran: NUS-USI President 2015-17|last= |first= |date=September 30, 2016 |website=NUS-USI |publisher=NUS-USI |access-date=April 30, 2017 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://theyworkforus.co.uk/2017/04/20/the-hidden-links-between-candidates-nusnc17/ |title=The Hidden Links Between Candidates?: #NUSNC17|last= |first= |date=April 20, 2017 |website=TheyWorkForUs|publisher= |access-date=April 30, 2017 |quote=}}</ref> In January 2017, [[Al Jazeera]] broadcast footage purporting to show that Brooks was involved in attempts to block the election of (and, later, discredit and remove) [[Malia Bouattia#Allegations of antisemitism|controversial]] President [[Malia Bouattia]] over allegations of [[antisemitism]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/01/exclusive-israel-lobby-infiltrates-uk-student-movement-170110140117749.html|title=Exclusive: Israel lobby infiltrates UK student movement|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=11 January 2017|accessdate=13 January 2017}}</ref> In response to Bouattia's election, students at [[Durham University|Durham]], [[Loughborough University|Loughborough]], [[University of Hull|Hull]], [[University of Aberystwyth|Aberystwyth]], [[University of Oxford|Oxford]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]], [[University of Manchester|Manchester]], [[University of Essex|Essex]], [[University of York|York]], [[King's College London]], [[University of Nottingham|Nottingham]], [[University of the West of England|UWE]], [[University of Leicester|Leicester]], [[Queen Mary University of London]] and [[Reading University]] had campaigned to disaffiliate from the NUS.<ref name="BBC230416">{{cite news|title=Students threaten to split from NUS over new president|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-36109164|accessdate=23 April 2016|work=[[BBC News]]|date=22 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thelinc.co.uk/2016/05/lincoln-su-disaffiliates-from-national-union-of-students/|title=Lincoln SU disaffiliates from National Union of Students|date=2016-05-09|website=The Linc|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-05-10}}</ref> Lincoln, Newcastle, Hull and Loughborough all disaffiliated.<ref>Slater, Tom. [http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2016/05/the-backlash-against-the-nus-has-begun/ The backlash against the NUS has begun.] ''[[The Spectator]]'', 12 May 2016. Retrieved 13 May 2016.</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Ali|first1=Aftab|title=Hull University Union becomes latest to disaffiliate from National Union of Students|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/student/news/hull-university-union-becomes-latest-to-disaffiliate-from-national-union-of-students-a7046696.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=24 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Jackman|first1=Josh|title=Loughborough University students vote to split from NUS|url=http://www.thejc.com/news/campus-news/159066/loughborough-university-students-vote-split-nus|work=The Jewish Chronicle|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref>
===2017-Present=== After this [[Malia Bouattia#Allegations of antisemitism|widespread discontentment]] with NUS' direction, the [[National Union of Students (United Kingdom)#2017 National Conference|2017 National Conference]] saw a [[slate (elections)|slate]] of OI-backed candidates win five of the six [[Governance of the National Union of Students (United Kingdom)#Full Time Officers|full-time officer positions]] elected at NUS National Conference.<ref name="Topping"></ref><ref name="Peake"></ref> In addition to this, several [[centrist]] [[motion (parliamentary procedure)|motions]] passed, including [[democratic reform|democratic reforms]] designed to better engage students and students' unions, which were described as "the most comprehensive and wide-ranging structural reforms in NUS history".<ref name="Lapwood">{{cite news|last1=Lapwood|first1=George|url=http://www.studentnewspaper.org/press-coverage-of-the-nus-is-dishonest-and-manipulative/|title=The NUS Conference was an overwhelming success. So why the obsession with ‘jazz hands’?|work=The Student Newspaper|date=29 April 2017|accessdate=30 April 2017}}</ref> WonkHE policy commentator Nona Buckley-Irvine wrote that with the "significant ideological shift from the hard left to more moderate candidates, sector bodies and universities will prepare themselves for a rethink in how to approach NUS going forward".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://wonkhe.com/blogs/policy-watch-watershed-moment-for-the-nus/|title=New leaders, new approach: a watershed moment for NUS|publisher=Wonkhe|author=Nona Buckley-Irvine| date=27 April 2017}}</ref>
In 2018, after a year of constructive engagement with policymakers, all returning candidates were re-elected except Izzy Lenga. Martin was re-elected with 51% of the vote in the first round of voting, along with deputy Amatey Doku, who received 68% after calling for nationwide student-led mobilisation to demand a 'people's vote' on the final [[Brexit]] deal.<ref name="Bothwell">{{cite news|last1=Bothwell|first1=Ellie|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/shakira-martin-re-elected-national-union-students-president|title=Shakira Martin re-elected as National Union of Students president|work=Times Higher Education|date=28 March 2018|accessdate=28 March 2018}}</ref><ref name="Weale">{{cite news|last1=Weale|first1=Sally|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/mar/28/shakira-martin-easily-holds-on-to-leadership-of-students-union|title=Shakira Martin easily holds on to leadership of students union|work=The Guardian|date=28 March 2018|accessdate=28 March 2018}}</ref><ref name="Sanderson">{{cite news|last1=Sanderson|first1=Daniel|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/student-chief-shakira-martin-reaches-out-to-tories-after-defeating-left-ln3bsjrd0|title=Student chief Shakira Martin reaches out to Tories after defeating left|work=The Times|date=31 March 2018|accessdate=31 March 2018}}</ref>
==Brexit== In 2018, in response to the ongoing political instability around [[Brexit]], the group launched [[For our Future's Sake|FFS]], a cross-party youth campaign for a [[People's Vote|people's vote]]. Key OI figures steered policy through the 2018 National Conference to ensure that NUS became one of the earliest organisations to declare support for the position.<ref>{{cite web | last = Pontone | first = Maya | title = Vice President of NUS mobilises ‘people’s vote’ on final Brexit deal | url = https://www.shoutoutuk.org/2018/03/30/vice-president-of-nus-mobilises-peoples-vote-on-final-brexit-deal/ | website = shoutoutuk.org | publisher = Shout Out UK | date = 30 March 2018 | access-date = 13 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Ramiro | first = Joana | title = NUS throws weight behind Brexit second ref | url = https://leftfootforward.org/2018/03/students-union-throws-weight-behind-brexit-second-ref/ | work = [[Left Foot Forward]] | date = 28 March 2018 | access-date = 13 September 2018}}</ref><ref name=FFSConferenceLaunch>{{cite news | url= https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/brexit-second-referendum-remain-chuka-ummuna-vote-community-labour-a8274601.html | work = [[The Independent]] | date = 28 March 2018 | access-date = 13 September 2018}}</ref>
The campaign subsequently organised an open letter undersigned by 120 student leaders, and numerous demonstrations, which attracted over 160,000 attendees.<ref>{{cite news | last1 = Helm | first1 = Toby | last2 = Boycott-Owen | first2 = Mason | title = Students plan summer of defiance in push for ‘people’s vote’ on Brexit | url = https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/may/12/students-plan-summer-of-defiance-on-brexit | work = [[The Observer]] | date = 12 May 2018 | access-date = 13 September 2018}}</ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== *[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/higher/its-tough-at-the-top--and-dirty-656420.html Article in The Independent on the power-struggle between Labour and OI in 2002] *[http://www.epolitix.com/EN/Interviews/200103/24487F2C-3501-4C36-A6BC-B3C87DDC7446.htm Epolitix.com interview with Owain James] *[http://www.national-student.co.uk/national_news/dirty_games_nus_presidential_election_stitch_up.htm National Student article on 2008 deal between OIs and Labour Students]
{{National Union of Students (United Kingdom)}}

revision.comment: WikiProject [[Category:Articles needing coordinates|Coordinates]] requirement deleted. The article refers to a scholarship program and is not associated with one physical location.
revision.text:
'''Osher Lifelong Learning Institutes''' ('''OLLI''') offer noncredit courses with no assignments or grades to “seasoned” adults over age 50. Since 2001 philanthropist '''[[Bernard Osher]]''' has made grants from his foundation to launch OLLI programs at 120 universities and colleges in all 50 states and the District of Columbia.
==Background== Bernard Osher, a native of [[Maine]], managed the family hardware and plumbing supply business before heading to New York to work for [[Oppenheimer & Company]]. He moved to California and became a founding director of [[World Savings]] and a founder of its parent company [[Golden West Financial]]. He bought the San Francisco auction house [[Butterfield & Butterfield]] in 1970 and sold it in 1999 to [[eBay]]. World Savings merged with [[Wachovia Corporation]] in 2006, which was in turn acquired by [[Wells Fargo]] in 2008. In 1977 he established the Bernard Osher Foundation, headquartered in [[San Francisco]], which contributes to higher education, the arts, and social services, with education receiving nearly 80 percent of its grants.<ref> {{cite web |title=Backstory: A California financier emerges as one of the nation’s most prolific philanthropists |url= http://features.csmonitor.com/backstory/2008/07/23/a-california-financier-emerges-as-one-of-the-nation’s-most-prolific-philanthropists/ |access-date=14 March 2009 |publisher=''Christian Science Monitor'' |date=2008-07-23 }} </ref>
Osher was impressed by the [[Fromm Institute for Lifelong Learning]] at the [[University of San Francisco]], and approached the Senior Program at the [[University of Southern Maine]] (USM) with his interest in supporting noncredit programs for older adults. He awarded USM an endowment grant in 2001 to expand its program, which was renamed as the first Osher Lifelong Learning Institute.<ref name="Osher Lifelong Learning Institutes">{{cite web |title=Osher Lifelong Learning Institutes |url=http://www.osherfoundation.org/index.php?olli |access-date=30 April 2017 |publisher=The Bernard Osher Foundation |year= }} </ref> Ed Stolman, a friend of Osher’s who had retired to [[Sonoma County, California]], approached [[Sonoma State University]] (SSU) to encourage development of an OLLI program.<ref> {{cite web |title=Senior Living: ‘Lifelong learning’ enthusiast explores creating model community |url=http://www1.pressdemocrat.com/article/20081110/BUSINESSJOURNAL/811070243 |access-date=15 March 2009 |publisher=''North Bay Business Journal'' |author=Jenna V. Loceff |date=2008-11-10 }} </ref> The Osher Foundation made a development grant to SSU which quickly attracted an audience of older student members. Encouraged by the success of these two programs, Osher decided to greatly expand his grant support for similar lifelong learning institutes.
==OLLI program development== In 2002 the Osher Foundation began making program development grants of $100,000 a year for up to three years to launch new OLLI programs. The initial focus was on California, which now has OLLI programs at seven [[University of California]] and 16 [[California State University]] campuses. In 2004 Osher established a National Resource Center at USM to distribute information about effective educational programs for older adults via a web site, a research journal, and an annual conference. In October 2014 the NRC was relocated to [[Northwestern University]]'s downtown [[Chicago, Illinois]] campus.<ref name="NRC">{{cite web |url=http://nrc.northwestern.edu/2015/04/the-national-resource-center-for-the-osher-lifelong-learning-institutes/ |title=The National Resource Center for Osher Lifelong Learning Institutes |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=April 15, 2015 |website=northwestern.edu |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref>
Under current practices, if an OLLI program has 500 fee-paying members by the end of its fourth year, the university is eligible for a $1 million endowment grant from the Osher Foundation. When it reaches 1000 members, it is eligible for another $1 million endowment grant. As of 2015, the Osher Foundation was supporting 120 OLLI programs at universities and colleges in all 50 states and the [[District of Columbia]].<ref name="Osher Lifelong Learning Institutes"/>
The Bernard Osher Foundation’s executive director is Barbro Osher, Consul General for [[Sweden]] in San Francisco.
==See also== *[[Lifelong learning]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.osherfoundation.org/index.php?index The Bernard Osher Foundation] *[http://nrc.northwestern.edu/ OLLI National Resource Center] [[Category:2001 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Lifelong learning]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in the United States]]

{{Orphan|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox company| | name = Rediker Software, Inc. | logo = [[File:Rediker logo.jpg|275px|Rediker Logo]] | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | foundation = {{Start date|1980}} | founder = Richard Rediker | location_city = [[Hampden, Massachusetts]] | location_country = USA | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Richard Rediker, CEO
Andrew Anderlonis, President
Susan Brady, Director of Sales | services = School Administrative Software | homepage = [http://www.rediker.com www.rediker.com]}} '''Rediker Software''' is a company that provides [[School management system|school administrative software]] to PK – 12 schools. Rediker Software employs about 100 people and is headquartered in [[Hampden, Massachusetts]]. Other supporting offices are located in [[India]] and [[Ecuador]]. The software is used by public and [[private school]]s in every [[United States|US]] state and more than 115 countries.{{cite web | url=http://www.rediker.com/testimonials-international.html | title=International Testimonials | publisher=Rediker Software | accessdate=August 11, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120911005205/http://www.rediker.com/testimonials-international.html | archivedate=September 11, 2012 | df= }} ==Company history== ===1980 - 1999=== Founder and CEO Richard Rediker began the development of Administrator’s Plus, the company's [[student information system]], over 35 years ago. As a chemistry teacher and class advisor in 1980, he developed an early program on the [[Commodore PET]] computer to automatically generate tardy letters. This program eventually became Administrator's Plus.{{cite news | url=http://www.masslive.com/business-news/index.ssf/2011/02/redicker_software_hampden_owes_{{Not a typo|exis|tance}}_tardy_children.html | title=Rediker Software of Hampden owes existence to a bunch of tardy school children | date=February 13, 2011 | accessdate=August 10, 2011 | last=Barry | first=Stephanie | newspaper=The Republican}} In 1981, the first license for Administrator's Plus was sold to [[Saint Mary High School (Westfield, Massachusetts)|St. Mary High School]] in [[Westfield, Massachusetts]]. The school still uses the software to this day.{{cite web | url=http://www.rediker.com/testimonials/st-mary-high | title=A Testimonial From St. Mary High School | publisher=Rediker Software | accessdate=August 11, 2011 | last=Reilley | first=Gill | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120911010227/http://www.rediker.com/testimonials/st-mary-high | archivedate=September 11, 2012 | df= }} In 1998, the company moved into their office located in the center of [[Hampden, Massachusetts]]. ===2000 - Present=== In 2006, the offices were expanded, including larger training facilities and expanded technical support offices. This same year, Rediker Software introduced the School Office Suite. In 2007, Administrator’s Plus became a [[Schools Interoperability Framework|SIF]]-certified application.{{cite web | url=http://www.sifinfo.org/us/members-profile.asp?id=78 | title=Rediker Software | publisher=SIF Association | accessdate=August 16, 2011}} In 2009, Rediker Software introduced Admissions Plus Pro, including online forms and applications, to help private schools increase enrollment and improve recruitment.{{cite press_release | url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/admissions-software/school-software/prweb2652894.htm | title=Rediker Software Revolutionizes the School Admissions Process with the Release of Admissions Plus Pro | publisher=PRWeb | date=July 20, 2009 | accessdate=August 16, 2011}} For the years of 2008 - 2016, the company has been named by the [[Affiliated Chambers of Commerce of Greater Springfield]] to their "Super 60" list of fastest-growing privately held companies in [[Western Massachusetts]].{{cite web | url=http://www.myonlinechamber.com/news-reader-page/items/accgs-announces-2008-super-60.html | title=ACCGS Announces 2008 Super 60 | work=Affiliated Chambers of Commerce of Greater Springfield | date=October 8, 2008 | accessdate=August 10, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web | url=http://www.myonlinechamber.com/news-reader-page/items/accgs-announces-2009-super-60.html | title=ACCGS Announces 2009 Super 60 | work=Affiliated Chambers of Commerce of Greater Springfield | date=September 30, 2009 | accessdate=August 10, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120910193628/http://www.myonlinechamber.com/news-reader-page/items/accgs-announces-2009-super-60.html | archivedate=September 10, 2012 | df= }}{{cite web | url=http://www.myonlinechamber.com/news-reader-page/items/2010-Super-60-Winners.html | title=ACCGS Announces 2010 Super 60 Winners | work=Affiliated Chambers of Commerce of Greater Springfield | date=January 6, 2011 | accessdate=August 10, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604152925/http://www.myonlinechamber.com/news-reader-page/items/2010-Super-60-Winners.html | archivedate=June 4, 2011 | df= }} In July 2012, Rediker Software rebranded with a new logo to reflect the company's move towards cloud-based solutions and also its commitment to the advancement of schools through educational technology solutions.{{cite web|last=Anderlonis|first=Amy|title=New Logo for a New Chapter|url=http://www.rediker.com/assets/news/Rediker_Software_Announces_New_Logo.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114040606/http://www.rediker.com/assets/news/Rediker_Software_Announces_New_Logo.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=14 November 2012|publisher=Rediker Software|accessdate=17 June 2013}} On June 3, 2013, [http://www.linkedin.com/pub/andrew-anderlonis/7/720/223 Andrew Anderlonis], former Director of Business Development and Operations and son-in-law to CEO Richard Rediker, was appointed President of Rediker Software.{{cite news|last=Anderlonis|first=Amy|title=Andrew Anderlonis Named New President of Rediker Software|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2013/6/prweb10788956.htm|accessdate=17 June 2013|newspaper=PRWeb|date=3 June 2013}} ==Products== {{Advert|section|date=September 2012}} *'''Administrator’s Plus''' is a student information system that manages school data on students and staff. Schools can use the system to track attendance, write [[Report Card|reports cards]], record disciplinary action and build student [[Block scheduling|schedules]]. Teachers can maintain a class webpage and calculate and record grades in the program. Administrators can create digital portfolios for each student and staff member. The system allows users to batch e-mail report cards and other documents to parents. Parents can log into the system from home to see their children’s [[Grade (education)|grades]] and other information, including school announcements. *'''Admissions Plus Pro''' is an enrollment management software program. Enrollees can submit forms online, and data is automatically entered into the Admissions Plus Pro or Administrator’s Plus. *'''Teacher Evaluator''' is a web-based application and [[iPad]] app. The application allows users to schedule and complete teacher evaluations. Teacher Evaluator includes state-mandated reports. Users may also create their own rubrics or edit pre-existing templates. ==Rediker Cares Project== Rediker Cares Project is Rediker Software’s volunteer program that gives employees the ability to volunteer at local organizations and events during company time. The program empowers employees to work together to give back to the local community and to help those in need. As a result, Rediker employees have made significant contributions to local organizations including Open Pantry{{cite press_release | url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2011/12/prweb9054229.htm | title=Rediker Software Employees Donate Time to Help Senior Citizens in Need | publisher=PRWeb | date=December 20, 2011 | accessdate=March 7, 2012}} and Links to Libraries.{{cite web | url=http://businesswest.com/2012/02/picturethis-9 | title=PictureThis | work=BusinessWest | date=28 February 2012 | accessdate=March 7, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608114511/http://businesswest.com/2012/02/picturethis-9 | archivedate=8 June 2012 | df= }} The project also donates school supplies to schools in developing countries and runs food drives and fundraisers for local non-profits. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.rediker.com Rediker Software] (official website) *[https://www.rediker.com/solutions/student-information-system Administrator's Plus] *[https://www.rediker.com/solutions/admissions-and-enrollment Admissions Plus Pro] *[https://www.rediker.com/solutions/evaluations-walkthroughs Teacher Evaluator] *[https://www.rediker.com/solutions/responsive-school-websites RediSite - Responsive School Websites] [[Category:Software companies based in Massachusetts]] [[Category:School-administration software]]

{{other people||Samuel Green (disambiguation){{!}}Samuel Green}} {{Infobox person | name = Samuel Fisk Green | image = Samuel fisk green.gif | image_size = 150px | birth_date = October 10, 1822 | birth_place = Worcester, Massachusetts | death_date = {{death date and age|1884|5|28|1822|10|10|mf=y}}<ref>{{Cite book |title=Life and letters of Samuel Fisk Green, M. D., of Green Hill |url=https://archive.org/details/lifelettersofsamgree|last=Cutler |first=Ebenezer |year=1891 |pages=420}}</ref> | death_place = Green Hills, Massachusetts | occupation = Physician, missionary }} '''Samuel Fisk Green''' (1822–1884) was an American medical missionary. He graduated from the College of Physicians and Surgeons in [[New York city]]. He served with the [[American Ceylon Mission]] (ACM) in [[Jaffna]], [[Sri Lanka]] during the period (1847–1873) when it was the [[British Empire|British colony]] of [[British Ceylon|Ceylon]]. During his tenure he founded the Sri Lanka's first medical hospital and school in what later became the [[Green Memorial Hospital]] in [[Manipay]] in the [[Jaffna peninsula]].<ref name=Ambi/><ref name="hospital"/> He translated and published over 4000 pages of medical literature from [[English language|English]] to [[Tamil language|Tamil]] as part of his efforts to train doctors in their native language. He was personally responsible for training over 60 native doctors of whom majority had their instructions in Tamil.
==Early life== Green was born in [[Worcester, Massachusetts|Worcester]], Massachusetts, to William E. Green and Julia Plimpton as the eighth of 11 children. After his secondary schooling, he was attracted to religion. In 1841 he went to [[New York City]] and joined the [[Protestant]] [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal]] Board of Missions. During this period he became interested in the medical profession and joined as a medical student and graduating as a doctor in 1845. In 1846, he joined the American Mission and along with a team of missionaries was sent to [[Ceylon]] now [[Sri Lanka]].<ref name=Ambi/> His brother was [[Andrew Haswell Green]], who was instrumental in completing [[New York City]]'s [[Central park]].<ref name="Macintyre"/>
Green retired to [[Green Hills, Massachusetts|Green Hills]], Massachusetts in 1873 due to ill health. He died in 1884.<ref name=Ambi>{{cite book|last=Ambihaipahar|first=R|title=Scientific Pioneer: Dr.Samuel Fisk Green|url=http://kanaga_sritharan.tripod.com/greensf.htm|year=1998|publisher=Dhulasi Publications|isbn=955-8193-00-3}}</ref><ref name="hospital">{{cite web|url=http://www.manipayhospital.com/|title=Green Memorial Hospital|year=2002|publisher=Friends of Manipay Hospital|accessdate=17 July 2011}}</ref><ref name="Macintyre">{{cite news|url=http://sundaytimes.lk/100314/Plus/plus_11.html|title=The human drama underneath the factual medical, historical material|last=Macintyre|first=Ernest|date=March 14, 2010|work=The Sunday Times|accessdate=17 July 2011}}</ref>
==Missionary work== After a four month trip from America, he moved to Ceylon via [[Madras Presidency]] in [[British India]] in 1847. He initially served at the ACM mission at the [[Batticotta Seminary]]. Although the locals were reluctant use his services, eventually with his capability he became well known for his medical skills. As he attracted a lot of patients and it distracted Batticotta seminaries primary task of education, he was moved to another ACM mission station in [[Manipay]] in 1848. At Manipay, in addition to providing medical services to patients who came in search of him, he established the first medical school to teach western medicine to the [[Sri Lankan Tamils|Tamil people of Jaffna]], thus opening, Sri Lanka's first medical hospital and teaching facility that became known as Green memorial hospital. Green Memorial Hospital was managed by the [[Jaffna Diocese of the Church of South India]] (JDCSI) the successor organization of ACM. It celebrated the 150th anniversary of the Green Memorial Hospital, and the ACM medical mission, in October 1998.<ref name=Ambi/>
==Translating from English to Tamil== Initially when Dr. Green appealed for assistance for the publication of some medical books in Tamil, the colonial government refused aid. But after a decade, the same government doubled its aid and also requested Dr. Green to superintend the preparation and printing of Sanitary and Medical action related literature in Cholera times. Dr. Green wanted to prepare the trained physicians to stay in their native villages to help the locals instead migrating to find work within the colonial administration. To teach western medicine in Tamil, he had to coin technical terms in Tamil, translate western medical books into Tamil and write medical books in Tamil. This meant the development of medical and scientific Tamil as different from the established literary Tamil. There was also a need to write medical treatises in simple Tamil for the benefit of the common people – the layman.<ref name=Ambi/><ref name="Macintyre"/>
== Bibliography == Following is a list of his Translations from English into Tamil and the year of publication. ;Non-Fiction * ''Cutter’s Anatomy, Physiology and Hygiene''. 204 pages 1857 * ''Maunsell’s Obstetrics'' 258 pages 1857 * ''Druitt’s Surgery'' 504 pages 1867 * ''Gray’s Anatomy'' 838 pages 1872 * ''[[Robert Hooper (physician)|Hooper]]'s Physician’s Vade Mecum'' 917 pages 1875 * ''Dalton’s Physiology'' 590 pages 1883 * ''Waring’s Pharmacopoeia of India'' 574 pages 1884 * ''Well’s Chemistry'' 516 pages 1875
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://thiruarumugam.com/ Medical Missionaries in Jaffna] *[http://siddhadreams.blogspot.com/2009_03_01_archive.html Pioneer of scientific Tamil] *[http://jdc.jefferson.edu/jpgreenletters/ John Plimpton Green Letters] Jefferson Digital Commons, Thomas Jefferson University
{{Authority control}}
